answerText: The Life of Lazarillo de Tormes and of His Fortunes and Adversities [or La vida de Lazarillo de Tormes y de sus fortunas y adversidades][10] The Battle of Aljubarrota seems to have inspired part of this work, which collects tale on the titular son of King Perion who fathers Esplandián after a night of illicit boning with Princess Oriana. Esplandián later tricks him down and murders him for defiling his mother, because Spain is crazy.
heading: Terrapin |2013 | Chris Ray - FINAL | 12 | Literature | World | College
subject: Literature
question: Question: Answer the following about early Iberian literature. For 10 points each: [10] This 16th-century Spanish work, a hallmark of picaresque literature, follows the titular scamp in his service to various corrupt church officials.
